content:
david said
You might want to investigate the mailmerge addon, as I believe that may address your issue.

Thank you very much for your suggestion.

I investigated the mailmerge addon and I think that it is a very good piece of software and (actually a plus!) it is updated so you can use it with the most recent releases of TB. I'll keep it in mind !!

However i must admit that I'm not so smart to use it or I can say that it has too much options and it is too much complicated for my needs ... that is ... I believe it has a too steep learnig curve for my needs.

Actually I want that the filter does the job for me (that is, it has to take a given mail and forward it always to the same recipients), but if I use this mailmerge addon (very sofisticated, no doubt) I must every time build a new draft after choosing which email I want to forward to someone else.

Of course I'm telling my thoughts because I believe that the addon you suggested doesn't fit for my needs, and I hope my explanation could be useful for any other user that has the same problem.

Therefore now I'm still back at the starting point... actually it should be very simple to add to the filters options the choice between forwarding to (to or cc some recipients) and forwarding to (bcc to the same recipients).

I'm really sure that this is a necessary feature, but maybe it is not so simple to include it in TB ... who knows...

In the meantime I'll still keep on waiting some other suggestion .... and I hope that somebody will find an easy way to solve my problem...sooner or later ...

Thank you again for your kind suggestion. Best Alberto
creator: ociciornie

content: Well, if it were a necessary feature, it would already be there. And, you're wanting to send to a blind address. Thunderbird cannot do that, and the internet SMTP servers can't do that. Mailmerge 'might' allow you to send separate messages to each. Good luck.

content:

I've never heard of this before, and it seems counter-intuitive.

content: Going to 91 first is recommended, as Thunderbird does it upgrade adjustments at new versions. Then, upgrade to 102. Do full backup with Thunderbird not running prior to each step. Very important. Some antivirus programs interfere, so if you use one, check that it has ability to leave Thunderbird alone. Going back to prior version is always problematic, so I advise, even if you experience difficulties, to stay the course until issue rectified. Be sure to do the backups.
creator: davidsk

content:
David, thanks for replying. Your reply creates a few additional questions:

  • By backup, are you talking about a backup of the files on my hard drive, or does Thunderbird have its own backup of just its files?
  • In either case, how do I restore the backup if something catastrophic occurs? This is especially pertinent if you're talking about a generic backup program like Norton Backup. I run Norton Backup monthly, but I would have no way of knowing what folders to restore to rebuild my Thunderbird email folders. On the other hand, if Thunderbird has its own backup/restore, is that something that's invoked from within Thunderbird?
  • You mentioned that some antivirus programs might interfere with Thunderbird.Were you referring to the antivirus program possibly interfering with the Thunderbird upgrade process? If so, I could simply turn off the antivirus and firewall parts of my antivirus program (Norton 360). Or were you talking about an antivirus program scanning emails for viruses and spam?

Thanks in advance for any and all responses.
creator: TampaTom

content:
I'll try to answer what I can. Thunderbird does have a backup feature, but only with ver 102, and only for profiles smaller than 2 gig. I have seen problems on the forum with attempted restores from commercial backup products, such as Norton and others. The problem, as I see it, is that automated products may do their backups while Thunderbird is running and that will always produce a corrupted backup. The only safe backup is one done when Thunderbird is not running. This is because Thunderbird does not release the files and backup software misses them. So, if you use a commercial backup product, use it when THunderbird is not running to be safe. The profile itself will be at c:\users|<yourID>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird. If you backup that folder, (again, when Thunderbird is NOT running), you will have a reliable backup. Restoring is simply copying it back to the same place.

I am no guru on antivirus issues, but the great majority of problems during upgrades are because some antivirus programs interfere with the update, causing a corrupted update. Some antivirus software have the facility to ignore email software. If possible, disabling antivirus is preferred during upgrade.
creator: davidsk

content: I have this issue as of 115. Instead of the menu being at the traditional top which makes sense and is like other windows (mostly) programs it is now interfering with its position. And the top now has all the context stuff which now forces you to look away from the area you are working in (e.g. mail) and move your eyes much further to say click on delete or maybe archive.
creator: wLindsay

content: SOLVED I was still having the problem. I could not send emails with my Gmail accounts. I can receive. I removed some Gmail accounts and restored them. I went through the granting of approval for Thunderbird to access the account etc. and still I could not send emails. I let Thunderbird set up the POP3 settings. I am using the Portable version of Thunderbird. 102.9.0 (32-bit) I have been happy with that for many years. It’s only since Google changed the login authorization that we/I am having trouble. Not one to give up, I went through all the settings and noticed that the SMTP was set to use Port 587. I changed it to the default 465 and lo and behold, it now works. Thunderbird had set the wrong Port.

content:
Server Name: outlook.office365.com Port: 995 Security: SSL/TLS Authentication: Normal Password

Note: Your Outlook/Hotmail account password won't work with Thunderbird's Normal Password authentication. Instead, what you need is an app password. See https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/account-billing/using-app-passwords-with-apps-that-don-t-support-two-step-verification-5896ed9b-4263-e681-128a-a6f2979a7944 for details. After you've created the app password, use that with Thunderbird.
